SENT.plain: We studied a previously healthy 25-year-old woman with the anterior spinal artery syndrome, a rare thoracocervical myelopathy with multiple potential etiologies
Quantitative and clinical sensory examination showed dissociated loss of pin-prick and temperature discrimination below the level of the lesion, with normal light touch, vibratory, and position sense
Magnetic resonance imaging was consistent with cervical spinal cord infarction
Median SEPs showed normal Erb's potential with absent spinal N13- and normal scalp N20- latency
Tibial SEPs showed normal lumbosacral responses and normal scalp P30- latency
Both median and tibial nerve stimulation produced cortical responses of unusually large amplitude (median 38 microV, tibial 17 microV)
We hypothesize that large SEP amplitudes in this patient resulted from loss of anterolateral inhibitory influences on the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system
